It doesn’t cover fighting, but where the rules limit weapon skill to the relevant vehicle-operation skill, your limit is Combat Driving instead.

element.name: Combat Piloting
element.prereq: Relevant vehicle-operation skill; cannot exceed Riding+4.
element.desc: This technique represents training at piloting under combat conditions. Use it instead of the relevant vehicle-operation skill whenever you roll to control your vehicle in battle. It doesn’t cover fighting, but where the rules limit weapon skill to the relevant vehicle-operation skill, your limit is Combat Piloting instead.

element.name: Double-Loading
element.prereq: Fast-Draw (Ammo); cannot exceed Fast-Draw (Ammo) skill.
element.desc: You’ve practiced simultaneously reloading two chambers of a multi-barreled gun or a revolver, or inserting two shells into the tube magazine of a shotgun. A successful Double-Loading roll gives all the benefits of Fast-Draw (GURPS High-Tech, p. 42) and means that each Ready maneuver taken to insert or manually extract one cartridge affects two cartridges. This shaves off one extra second per pair of cartridges if the firearm ejects all of its casings at once, or two extra seconds per pair if the weapon requires you to extract each empty by hand.

element.name: Dual-Weapon Attack (Guns)
element.prereq: Any shooting skill; cannot exceed prerequisite skill.
element.desc:
If you attack with two guns at once, you’re normally at -4 on each attack unless you have Extra Attack. This technique lets you buy off that penalty. To remove the extra -4 for the “off” hand, you’ll also need either Ambidexterity (GURPS Basic Set, p. 39) or Off-Hand Weapon Training (GURPS Tactical Shooting, p. 39).
DWA is primarily for Guns (Pistol), but can be learned for any shooting skill. The only absolute requirement is that you can use two weapons at once. DWA is seldom learned by realistic shooters (see Akimbo Shooting, GURPS Tactical Shooting, p. 32).
You must learn DWA separately for each skill.
Per GURPS Basic Set, p. 417, when both attacks target the same foe, he defends at -1. Against guns, this only affects parries like attempts to slap the gun away in close combat (GURPS Tactical Shooting, p. 25-26). Dodge is unaffected.

element.name: Fanning
element.prereq: Guns (Pistol); cannot exceed Guns (Pistol) skill.
element.desc: This technique lets you buy off the basic -4 to Guns (Pistol) for fanning a single-action revolver with RoF 1 held in one hand. See Fanning (GURPS High-Tech, p. 14). Historically, Fanning wasn’t common with real gunfighters, but popular with trick shooters.

element.name: Fast-Firing
element.prereq: Guns; cannot exceed Guns.
element.desc: This technique lets you buy off the first -4 to skill for fast-firing a weapon with RoF 2 or 3. See Fast-Firing (GURPS High-Tech, p. 14).

element.name: Immediate Action
element.prereq: Armoury or any shooting skill; cannot exceed prerequisite skill.
element.desc: This technique permits you to buy off the basic -4 to clear a stoppage. See Immediate Action (GURPS High-Tech, p. 17). When learning Immediate Action, base shooting skill on IQ, not on DX. Shooting skill versions default to the Armoury specialty used with the relevant weapons, also at -4, but you must still choose a shooting skill specialty, not an Armoury one.

element.name: Masked Shooting
element.prereq: Any shooting skill; cannot exceed Guns (Pistol) skill-1 or any other prerequisite skill-2.
element.desc: You can reduce the basic -4 to shoot a weapon while wearing a diving mask, gas mask, etc. See Sighted Shooting (GURPS Tactical Shooting, p. 13). Long arms specialties like Rifle, Shotgun, and SMG can’t be improved to better than Guns-2 since such masks prevent proper cheek weld.

element.name: Precision Aiming
element.prereq: Guns and Observation; cannot exceed Guns.
element.desc: This technique enables you to buy off the –6 to Guns when rolling to claim extra Aim bonuses. See Precision Aiming (GURPS High-Tech, p. 26-27). Rifle is by far the most common specialty! When learning this technique, base shooting skill on IQ, not on DX.

element.name: Quick-Shot
element.prereq: Guns; cannot exceed Guns.
element.desc: This technique lets you buy off the –6 to use a RoF 2+ gun to shoot two targets in one second. See Shooting at Several Opponents (GURPS High-Tech, p. 17-18).

element.name: Retain Weapon (Guns)
element.desc: You must specialize by Guns specialty. When wielding a suitable weapon, you may use Retain Weapon instead of DX whenever somebody actively tries to disarm you (GURPS Basic Set, p. 401). Should an adversary try to disarm you using brute strength, you may make a ST-based Retain Weapon roll instead of a ST roll; find your ST-based level by subtracting DX and adding ST. This is commonly trained by modern law-enforcement officers.

element.name: Targeted Attack (TA)
element.prereq: Guns, Gunner, or Liquid Projector; special maximum.
element.desc:
Hits on “high-value” targets – face, chinks in armor, weapons, etc. – are effective fight-stoppers. Policemen often aim for the legs and special-ops soldiers for the brain (see The Mozambique Drill, GURPS High-Tech, p. 15-16).
For each Targeted Attack (TA), the gunman must specify a shooting skill and a target. The target can be any hit location other than the torso (Eye, Face, Arm, etc.), chinks in armor at a specific hit location (e.g., Torso Chinks), or Weapon. The shooting skill must be capable of attacking that target – usually relevant for attacks against vitals or skull (GURPS Basic Set, p. 399-400).
Default penalty: equal to the modifier to hit the target: –2: Arm, Leg –3: Groin, Pelvis, Vitals –4: Hand, Foot –5: Face, Neck –7: Skull –9: Eye
For chinks in armor: –10 for any location (replaces that location’s penalty), except –8 for torso chinks.
Weapon: assume –4; roll at +1 vs. large weapons (rifle, etc.), –1 vs. small ones (dagger, holdout pistol, etc.).
By improving TA, the shooter can buy off up to half of the default penalty (round up). Write the technique as “TA (Specialty/Target)”.
Examples: TA (Pistol/Leg) defaults to Guns (Pistol)-2 and can’t exceed Guns-1. TA (SMG/Skull) defaults to Guns (SMG)-7 and can’t exceed Guns-3.

element.name: Thumbing
element.prereq: Guns (Pistol); cannot exceed Guns (Pistol) skill.
element.desc: This technique allows you to buy off the –2 to Guns (Pistol) for thumbing a revolver. See Thumbing (GURPS High-Tech, p. 14).

element.name: Two-Handed Thumbing
element.prereq: Guns (Pistol); cannot exceed Guns (Pistol) skill.
element.desc: This technique permits you to buy off the –2 to Guns (Pistol) for thumbing a single-action revolver held in two hands. See Two-Handed Thumbing (GURPS High-Tech, p. 14).

element.name: Work by Touch (Guns)
element.prereq: Armoury (Small Arms); cannot exceed prerequisite skill.
element.desc: Changing a barrel, clearing a major malfunction, and many other non-combat Armoury applications are at –5 if you must work by touch – e.g., in the dark or while wearing night-vision goggles (GURPS Tactical Shooting, p. 19-20). With sufficient practice, it becomes second nature.

element.name: Bite
element.desc:
The basic bite attack. Note that you must be in close combat to bite. Brawling adds damage as normal.
† With the Biting Mastery perk, use Karate for the default, maximum, and damage bonus.

element.name: Rake
element.prereq: Brawling or Karate, and the Claws advantage; cannot exceed prerequisite skill.
element.desc:
This technique requires that both the attacker and target are prone, face-up, or crawling, and that the attacker has grappled the target. Some creatures set up this attack for the following turn by taking All-Out Attack (Double) to perform a flying tackle, pounce, or slam followed by a grappling attempt. Note that creatures with unusual postures or numbers of limbs may not need to meet these conditions; in these cases, the GM may wish to modify the technique as required.
Rake is a form of All-Out Attack (Double), and replaces the rules for that maneuver. The aggressor holds his enemy with both hands, tucks his legs up between them, and tears downward with both feet, ripping into his target’s abdomen or thighs with his claws.
Roll to attack twice, once for each foot. Each successful attack inflicts thrust+2 crushing damage, plus the Brawling or Karate bonus. Claws on the feet add any damage bonus, and may change this damage from crushing. The attacker must choose between targeting the torso with both attacks, or the legs with one attack each. The legs may be targeted without the usual -2.

element.name: Scratch
element.prereq: Brawling or Karate, and the Claws advantage; cannot exceed prerequisite skill.
element.desc:
This is a claw attack intended to tear the skin, causing shallow wounds that bleed profusely. Roll damage normally as for a hand attack. If any damage at all penetrates armor and natural DR, the target takes 1 point of injury only, but rolls for bleeding (GURPS Basic Set, p. 420) at -1 per scratch sustained.
At the GM’s discretion, this can have additional effects. For example, a scratch attack to the face (at a further -5) sends blood into the target’s eyes, causing Vision penalties of -3 or more, while inflicting scratches all over the target’s body for several turns may force a Fright Check.

element.name: Underwater Combat
element.prereq: Any Melee Weapon skill.
element.desc:
Attacks made with melee weapons underwater normally suffer a penalty of -4 per yard of maximum reach, even if used to attack at closer range (GURPS Martial Arts: Yrth Fighting Styles, p. 22). Someone trained in underwater combat may apply the penalty to his level in this technique instead of to the prerequisite skill. However, final effective skill with this technique cannot exceed base skill minus half the underwater penalty.
Example: An adventurer with Spear-15 and Underwater Combat (Spear)-21 wields a long spear: Reach 2, 3, for -12 underwater. His effective skill is 21-12 = 9. This is also equal to 15 (base skill) - 6 (half the underwater penalty).
If he later picks up a shorter spear – Reach 1, 2, for just -8 underwater – his skill doesn’t rise to 21-8 = 13, because it is capped at 15 (base skill) - 4 (half the underwater penalty) = 11.
Underwater versions of other techniques may default from the Underwater Combat technique. The default is based on the fighter’s effective skill, as calculated above.
For instance, if the person in the example invested 3 points in Targeted Attack (Underwater Spear Thrust/Vitals), altering the penalty for a vitals strike from -3 to -1, his effective skill when thrusting for the vitals with the Reach 1, 2 spear would be 10 (the capped underwater skill of 11, minus 1 for the Targeted Attack).
Both the underwater skill cap and the Targeted Attack cap apply.
A cinematic underwater warrior with the Terrain Adaptation (Underwater) advantage (GURPS Martial Arts: Yrth Fighting Styles, p. 24) has no need for this technique.

element.name: Coordinated Attack
element.prereq: Any combat skill.
element.desc:
Fighters who practice together may learn this technique for use when coordinating with members of that group only. It has no maximum level.
Apply Coordinated Attack modifiers to this technique and use the result instead of combat skill for the attack. If it exceeds combat skill, reduce it to that level before applying other modifiers.

element.name: Cutting Out
element.prereq: Any Per-based social interaction skill; cannot exceed prerequisite skill.
element.desc:
Normally, all the members of a small cohesive group will react to you as indicated by a single reaction roll or Influence roll (see Approachability, GURPS Social Engineering, p. 25). This technique lets you spot one member of the group who is susceptible to being approached as an individual.
You receive +1 to his reaction roll (+3 on a critical success); the reaction roll for the rest is unaffected. If you prefer, you may apply the bonus to an Influence roll against your specific target.

element.name: Going Viral
element.prereq: Propaganda and Psychology (Applied); cannot exceed Propaganda+3.
element.desc: Viral marketing (GURPS Social Engineering, p. 62) involves crafting a message that makes members of the audience want to repeat it or pass it along. The bonus from improving this technique replaces the bonus from spending more on a campaign, without requiring a higher budget; you cannot claim both benefits.

element.name: Hinting
element.prereq: Any Influence skill; cannot exceed prerequisite skill+6.
element.desc:
Hinting makes you skilled at influencing others without being obvious to bystanders. Each Influence skill has its own associated Hinting technique.
You may use your technique to offset skill penalties from subtlety (GURPS Social Engineering, p. 36), while still suffering Perception and Observation penalties normally.
Apply all penalties for subtlety to this technique, then roll against the lower of: • your modified technique, or • your unmodified Influence skill.
Thus, bonuses from Hinting can only offset subtlety penalties, never give a net bonus.

element.name: Irony
element.prereq: Public Speaking or Writing; cannot exceed prerequisite skill+5.
element.desc:
You are skilled at negative arguments that undermine an opponent’s position (see Dialectic, GURPS Social Engineering, p. 35), giving a bonus to the audience’s effective Will to resist adopting his point of view.
This technique lets you offset the penalties to your own effective skill that result from using irony, increasing your ability to make your points indirectly.
Apply all penalties for irony to this technique, then roll against the lower of: • your modified technique, or • your unmodified presentation skill.
Thus, bonuses from Irony can only offset irony penalties, never give a net bonus.

element.name: Sociometry
element.prereq: Sociology and Mathematics (Statistics); cannot exceed Sociology+5.
element.desc: You have mastered mathematical techniques for analyzing social networks and identifying key members within them. You can spot nonobvious relationships in a social situation (Relationships, GURPS Social Engineering, p. 26), social arbiters of exclusive communities (Inner Circles, GURPS Social Engineering, p. 59), or alpha users for viral marketing campaigns (GURPS Social Engineering, p. 62).

element.name: Dream Rehearsal
element.prereq: Dreaming; cannot exceed Dreaming+5.
element.desc: Consciously reliving successful default skill use in dreams can help you acquire the skill. Roll vs. Dream Rehearsal, halve your margin of success, and round up to find your bonus to IQ rolls for points-based learning (GURPS Social Engineering: Back to School, p. 5-7). Any success gives a minimum of +1; critical success always gives at least +5.

element.name: Memory Palace
element.desc:
As described by Roman orators, who called this the method of loci, you visualize a building, including its furnishings and rooms. To retain information (e.g., the key points of a speech), link each fact to an object that you place somewhere in the building. For example, if the murder weapon was a knife, visualize a bloody knife on the kitchen table.
You can roll against Memory Palace to recall specific facts (roll at IQ-5 if you have no training). Each point invested in the technique gives +1 to IQ rolls for Points-Based Learning (GURPS Social Engineering: Back to School, p. 5-7) and to the number of points you can spend on Heroic Learning (GURPS Social Engineering: Back to School, p. 19-20). Putting five points into Memory Palace means you’ve acquired Eidetic Memory! If you already have Eidetic Memory, learning Memory Palace is of no benefit – it doesn’t help you advance toward Photographic Memory, even if that’s learnable in your campaign.

element.name: Versification
element.prereq: Poetry; cannot exceed Poetry+4.
element.desc: You can put information in poetic form to aid in remembering it. Your verses aren’t literary art, but they’re understandable and catchy. For anything you’ve versified, you can recall specific details by making an IQ roll, as with Eidetic Memory. If Eidetic Memory would give you +5, you gain +1 to IQ per two points of success at a Versification roll, rounded up. Any success gives +1, and a critical success always gives at least +5.

element.name: Eavesdropping
element.prereq: Possession; cannot exceed Possession-3.
element.desc: You can perceive the surface thoughts of your opponent as though you were using Mind Reading (GURPS Basic Set, p. 69) against him. You must take a Concentrate maneuver, spend 3 MCP, and win a Quick Contest of IQ vs. the higher of your opponent’s Trained Will or Mind Block. Win or lose, the effects are identical to those of Mind Reading.

element.name: Enervation
element.prereq: Possession; cannot exceed Possession technique.
element.desc: You must already be engaged in a possession to use this technique. Roll against Enervation to hit; your opponent defends normally. If you hit, you must spend MCP to set the upper boundary for fatigue, but Mental Control Points spent on Enervation count double for this purpose. After spending MCP, roll a Quick Contest of your Trained Will against the better of your opponent’s Trained HT or Trained Will. If you win, you inflict the lesser of your margin of success or twice the MCP spent as fatigue damage.

element.name: Feint (Possession)
element.default: Exorcism, Meditation-2, Mental Strength, Possession, or Trained Will.
element.prereq: Possession; cannot exceed prerequisite skill+4.
element.desc: Feints represent lulls in the mental assault to draw a host into false confidence, mixing up types of attacks or tactics, etc. This technique replaces any attack or defense skill for the purpose of making or resisting feints. Beats (GURPS Martial Arts, p. 100-101) based on ST don’t make sense, but ruses (GURPS Martial Arts, p. 101) are certainly fitting.

element.name: Inquisition
element.prereq: Eavesdropping; cannot exceed Eavesdropping technique.
element.desc: You can dig into your opponent’s mind and root out specific knowledge he possesses as though you are using Mind Probe (GURPS Basic Set, p. 69). You must take a Concentrate maneuver, spend 3 MCP, and win a Quick Contest of IQ or Interrogation vs. the higher of his Trained Will or Mind Block. Win or lose, the effects are identical to those of Mind Probe.

element.name: Mental Contact
element.prereq: Possession; cannot exceed Possession technique.
element.desc: You may take a Concentrate maneuver, spend 3 MCP, and roll against Mental Contact to convey a short message directly to your host’s mind. This is completely nonvocal and cannot be heard by anyone else. The message may be spoken words, images, emotions, etc., but they do not hamper the host in any way – they merely communicate information.

element.name: Possession
element.prereq: Cannot exceed controlling attribute/characteristic.
element.desc: This technique allows you to buy off the -6 penalty to IQ when making possession attacks.

element.name: Stagger
element.prereq: Possession; cannot exceed Possession technique.
element.desc: Often employed to create an opening, this technique allows you to stun your opponent. You must be engaged in a possession attempt and win a Quick Contest of Stagger vs. the highest of your opponent’s Trained Will, IQ, or Mental Strength. If you win, your opponent must roll against IQ. On a failure, he’s mentally stunned. This is an attack.

element.name: Steal Possession
element.prereq: Possession; cannot exceed Possession technique.
element.desc: Make a possession attack against someone else’s host normally. If you succeed in inflicting MCP, reduce the possessor’s hold on the host by the amount rolled, and increase your own grip by as much.

element.name: Terrorize
element.prereq: Mental Contact; cannot exceed Mental Contact technique.
element.desc: You can truly terrify your potential host. Take a Concentrate maneuver, spend 3 MCP, and roll a Quick Contest of Trained Will. You may substitute Intimidation or Kiai, and your opponent may substitute Mental Strength. If you win, your opponent rolls 3d plus your margin of victory and looks up the effect on the Fright Check Table (GURPS Basic Set, p. 360).

element.name: Exercises
element.prereq: Teaching and a combat or athletic skill; cannot exceed Teaching+3.
element.desc:
Creates a series of movements – such as a drill or a kata – suited for practicing the basics of a skill. Useful for the first two points in a skill, but not for higher levels. In addition to improving Teaching skill for the purpose of instructing a class or preparing instructional materials, each point in the technique gives +1 to students’ monthly study rolls (GURPS Social Engineering: Back to School, p. 5).
At the GM’s option, Exercises may be applied to performing-arts skills, intellectual skills, or even some social skills such as Savoir-Faire (High Society, Military, or Servant).

element.name: Legendary Teaching
element.prereq: Teaching and a relevant special advantage.
element.desc:
You’re one of those rare teachers who train true heroes in their skills, as the centaur Chiron trained Achilles, Heracles, and Theseus. Whether through inspiration, divine wisdom, or advanced scientific methods, you can pass on knowledge extraordinarily quickly, teach cinematic skills and techniques, and even impart mastery comparable to your own. Legendary Teaching is the basis of Heroic Learning (GURPS Social Engineering: Back to School, p. 19-20); the rules for it appear there.
The archetypal “relevant special advantage” for this technique is Trained by a Master, but similar combat-related advantages (Gunslinger, Heroic Archer, Weapon Master, etc.) are no less fitting. Other spheres call for different advantages: Charisma 3+ for Influence and social skills; Gadgeteer for technological skills; Harmony with the Tao (GURPS Thaumatology: Chinese Elemental Powers, p. 15) for peaceful cinematic skills; Magery 3+ for spells and magical skills; and three levels of a power Talent for powers.
At the GM’s discretion, three levels of a skill-related Talent may grant access to this technique, as an alternative benefit that replaces the reaction bonus (see GURPS Power-Ups 3: Talents, p. 18-19). Enlightened Teacher (GURPS Social Engineering: Back to School, p. 20) lets you teach any skill you know in this way!

element.name: Grabbing Parry (Alternate)
element.prereq: Judo, Sumo Wrestling, or Wrestling; cannot exceed prerequisite Parry-1.
element.desc:
While in close combat, you can grab an attacking limb with a Grabbing Parry. With an extra -1, you may grab the attacking hand or foot instead. Grabbing Parry is one-handed or one-armed; if you use Cross Parry (GURPS Martial Arts, p. 121), which gives +1 to your defense, you may grab with both hands/arms.
If the attacker has the Rapid Retraction perk, your margin of victory must be at least 2 for you to successfully grab. This replaces the rules for Judo Parry setups and realistic uses of Hand Catch.

element.name: Grabbing Parry
element.prereq: Judo, Sumo Wrestling, Wrestling, or appropriate Melee Weapon skill; cannot exceed prerequisite Parry.
element.desc:
This technique replaces Hand Catch.
When attacked with a strike or an attempt to grapple a new location, you may try to grab your foe during the parry! You may not use Grabbing Parry if your foe is attacking to improve an existing grapple. Choose a legal parry and defense option (if desired); you can capture a striking arm (or weapon!), grab a kick, slip in and grapple the torso (see Retreat Options, GURPS Martial Arts, p. 123), etc. Success grapples your foe with the limbs used, but inflicts CP based on 0.5 × ST regardless.
You may capture the leg or the foot at Reach C, or just the foot at Reach 1 – but to follow up with grappling techniques, you must enter close combat.
Parrying a swung weapon with Grabbing Parry can be very dangerous. Unless the fighter can step into close combat and parry the attacker’s limbs, apply Harsh Realism for Unarmed Fighters (GURPS Martial Arts, p. 124) to inflict half damage to all parrying limbs even on a successful parry (one arm for Judo, two arms for Sumo Wrestling or Wrestling); reduce damage by 1 for every point by which the parry is made.
Modifiers: Against unarmed: • -1 to grapple an armored leg, -2 for a hand or foot; • -1 per level of foe’s Rapid Retraction (Pyramid 3/34: Alternate GURPS, p. 30).
Against armed: • -3 if using Judo or parrying a thrust with Sumo Wrestling or Wrestling, • -6 if parrying a swing with Sumo Wrestling or Wrestling; • an extra -3, -4, or -5 if the goal is to bypass a Reach C, 1, or 2+ weapon, respectively, to grab the arm or hand holding it.

element.name: Power Techniques
element.default: Controlling attribute at the penalty assigned by the relevant advantage.
element.prereq: Possession of an advantage that assigns a specific penalty to a particular use; cannot exceed controlling attribute or the associated power skill.
element.desc:
Power Techniques allow characters to “buy off” the penalties that certain advantages impose on specific special actions. Each such specialized feat becomes a Hard technique that defaults to the controlling attribute at the penalty listed in the description of the advantage. The technique may be improved normally, but cannot exceed the controlling attribute. If the campaign uses power skills, then Power Techniques default to the appropriate power skill at the same penalty, and their maximum level is capped by that skill.
At the GM’s discretion, characters without full powers may still learn individual Power Techniques if they possess a suitable ability that justifies the feat, but only characters with true powers may benefit from power Talent or power skills when improving these techniques.
Example: Healing is at -6 to repair a crippled limb. The GM may allow a healer to learn Repair Limb as a Hard technique. It defaults to IQ-6 and cannot exceed IQ (or default+6). In a game using power skills, it would default to Healing-6 and could not exceed the Healing skill.

element.name: Running the Pole
element.prereq: Acrobatics; cannot exceed Acrobatics.
element.desc: Roll against Running the Pole each turn to avoid falling! Attacks and defenses suffer the usual penalties for bad footing. The default of -2 assumes smooth, level ground. On rough or uneven ground, apply another -2 that can’t be bought off. The Chariot Training perk in GURPS Low-Tech halves this extra -2 and eliminates bad-footing penalties.

element.name: Setup Attack
element.prereq: Any unarmed or Melee Combat skill; cannot exceed prerequisite skill.
element.desc: A setup attack is used to impose a defensive penalty on a fighter’s next attack, as long as that attack is launched on his current or immediately following turn. A successful setup attack is a real attack, and if it succeeds, it strikes home as usual. In addition, a successful attack imposes -2 to Parry, as well as -1 to Block and Dodge. Turning Setup Attack into a technique makes it viable for explicit inclusion into Combinations (see GURPS Martial Arts, p. 80).

element.name: Sight-Reading
element.prereq: Musical Instrument or Singing, and cannot have Can’t Read Music; cannot exceed prerequisite skill.
element.desc: In societies that have musical notation, playing a new piece from written music gives -2 for unfamiliarity. A musician who improves Sight-Reading can roll against it instead to play any unfamiliar piece straight from the written music.

element.name: Trading in Illegal Goods
element.prereq: Merchant; cannot exceed prerequisite skill.
element.desc: Merchants who lack Streetwise at 12 or more and don’t specialize in illegal goods are at -3 when dealing with these. However, a relatively unconnected fence (Streetwise 11 or less) – even if he’s an amateur – can still learn the basics about these dangerous ventures.

element.name: Debugging
element.prereq: Any skill useful for operating a newly invented device; cannot exceed prerequisite skill.
element.desc: When testing a new invention, roll once weekly vs. the relevant version of Debugging to find bugs (see GURPS Basic Set, p. 474, 476). Identifying the appropriate skill may take some creativity! For example, plausible operating skills for Ontogenetics (GURPS Powers: The Weird, p. 11-12) are Animal Handling and Teaching.

element.name: Facing Change
element.prereq: Acrobatics or Body Sense; cannot exceed Body Sense+5 or Acrobatics+2.
element.desc: During movement into or out of hyperspace, you can alter your body’s orientation as a free action and without disorientation. Roll at -2 if you change facing or at -5 if you go from horizontal to vertical or vice versa. Your effective skill after the penalty cannot exceed Body Sense or Acrobatics-3.

element.name: Heuristics
element.prereq: Illuminated and Philosophy; cannot exceed Philosophy skill.
element.desc: Heuristics is the art of discovering the truth, guided by philosophical insight into the nature of reality. A successful Heuristics roll grants +2 to any skill used to discover an unknown truth or reach a moral decision. Critical success gives +4. Failure produces no insight; critical failure sets you on the wrong track, so that only critical success on the primary skill can point you to the truth.

element.name: Illumination
element.prereq: Illuminated and Teaching; cannot exceed Teaching skill.
element.desc: You have special methods of instruction suited to passing on the Illuminated state (GURPS Basic Set, p. 60). These are based largely on asking questions the student must reflect on at length between face-to-face sessions. Treat this as intensive training (GURPS Basic Set, p. 293), but dependent on Will rather than HT.

element.name: Inspired Development
element.prereq: Gadgeteer and any skill useful with it; cannot exceed prerequisite skill+4.
element.desc: You’re cinematically gifted at turning sketchy plans into working models. You must specialize in a skill useful for inventing. When making a Prototype roll using that skill, apply all relevant modifiers to your Inspired Development level. Then use the lower of your modified technique or unmodified inventing skill for your Prototype roll.

element.name: Inspired Research
element.prereq: Gadgeteer and any skill useful with it; cannot exceed prerequisite skill+4.
element.desc: You’re cinematically gifted at dreaming up radical new inventions. You must specialize in a skill useful for inventing. When making a Concept roll using that skill, apply all relevant modifiers to your Inspired Research level. Then use the lower of your modified technique or unmodified inventing skill for your Concept roll.

element.name: Mind Modification (Trait)
element.prereq: Brainwashing, Hypnotism, Propaganda, Psychology, or Teaching; cannot exceed prerequisite skill+6.
element.desc: Used to remove or add one specific mental or behavioral trait with a particular skill. Apply -1 to your Mind Modification level per full 5 points of the trait removed or added. Then use the lower of your modified technique or unmodified skill for the roll. Base time required is eight hours; multiple sessions grant a bonus for extra time (GURPS Basic Set, p. 346). Using Telesend in this process gives +2.

element.name: Projection
element.prereq: Intuitive Mathematician, Mathematics (Pure), Meditation, and Style Familiarity (Tesseraxis); cannot exceed Meditation skill.
element.desc:
A roll vs. Projection allows you to visualize and enter four-dimensional space; see Tesseraxis (GURPS Powers: The Weird, p. 13). If you concentrate for one minute (the shortest possible time), your Projection roll is at -5; taking extra time (GURPS Basic Set, p. 346) gives bonuses that can compensate for this. You have an additional penalty equal to twice your encumbrance level (e.g., Heavy encumbrance gives -6). Successful or not, the attempt costs 1 FP.
Entering four-dimensional space – or maneuvering there – requires a roll against Body Sense (GURPS Powers: The Weird, p. 5). You don’t gain the ability to breathe (see Hyperspace, GURPS Powers: The Weird, p. 15), and must hold your breath (GURPS Basic Set, p. 351-352). You can take oxygen with you, but the weight will make Projection harder to achieve.

element.name: Remote Hypnosis
element.prereq: Charisma 1 and Hypnotism; cannot exceed Hypnotism skill.
element.desc:
In settings where hypnotism is a quasi-mystical process (Psychical Research, GURPS Powers: The Weird, p. 13), a hypnotist may be able to induce a hypnotic trance in a previous subject at a distance. Base time required is five minutes. If Remote Hypnosis succeeds, the subject is in a trance. This may be a trigger for previously implanted suggestions (possibly including “Telephone for instructions”), or a second Remote Hypnosis roll might implant new suggestions, with precision limited as for the Suggest skill (GURPS Basic Set, p. 191).
Modifiers: Hypnotism modifiers (GURPS Basic Set, p. 201); bonus equal to hypnotist’s Charisma; standard range penalties (GURPS Basic Set, p. 550); and modifiers for haste or extra time (GURPS Basic Set, p. 346). If hypnotist and subject have a Special Rapport (GURPS Basic Set, p. 88), the roll is at +5 and base time is only five seconds.

element.name: Batching
element.desc: When making an elixir, an alchemist may accept a -1 penalty to his skill to brew another elixir of the same type, making a “batch” of that elixir. With this technique, you may buy off this penalty for making larger amounts of a given elixir. You must specialize by elixir type and form, which defaults to the base elixir technique; for example, Batching (Endurance/Potion) would be valid but Batching (Endurance) would not. While this technique has no actual limit, you would use the lower of this technique or the unmodified elixir technique when making elixir batches (you can’t get a bonus for making fewer potions).

element.name: Identify Magical Item
element.desc: When identifying a possible magical item through Alchemy rather than magic (GURPS Magic, p. 212), use this technique instead.

element.name: Identify Elixir
element.desc: When identifying an elixir (GURPS Magic, p. 212), use this technique instead of your Alchemy.

element.name: Control (Body Part)
element.default: DX, Judo, Sumo Wrestling, Wrestling; cannot exceed default.
element.desc:
This basic technique allows you to control specific body parts. For example, Control Arm can force your opponent to pull a lever and, defensively, stop his punch, Parry, or aim. Control Hand can make him drop a remote or stop him from pulling a trigger. Control Torso can stop his Dodge. Control techniques cannot force someone to make unarmed/melee attacks or active defenses.
• Control Torso is at -4 for a hand or foot grapple; -3 for two extremities (hands or feet); -2 for a neck, head, arm, or leg grapple; or -1 for two limbs or for one limb and either the neck or head. • Controlling a limb is at -2 for grappling the torso or the limb’s extremity. • Control Head works at -2 for a neck grapple, and Control Neck works at -2 for a head grapple.
You can use control techniques to defend against strikes, grabs, or grappling techniques performed with the controlled body part. For defending against grappling techniques, this might only be advantageous if you have a specific setup (see Setup on Pyramid 3/34: Alternate GURPS, p. 17) or are using extra limbs.

element.name: Control Position
element.default: DX-3, Judo-3, Sumo Wrestling-3, Wrestling-3; cannot exceed default+2.
element.desc:
This technique uses the same location penalties as Control Torso (above). Your opponent may substitute HP for ST in the Grappling Contest when resisting. Use Control Position to rotate your opponent to change his facing, orientation, or posture. If you are rolling and changing posture with him, without changing your relative facing/orientation/posture, you gain +1 and may substitute HP for ST.
Add -2 to change his relative facing between front and rear or between opposite sides. Add -2 to move him from a ground posture to standing. Defensively, use Control Position to stop your foe from changing facing, posture, or orientation. Rotating your foe around is harder when he grapples you; see Taking the Back (above).
Control Position still uses penalties for posture (GURPS Basic Set, p. 231 and GURPS Martial Arts, p. 73), which can be offset by the Low Fighting and Ground Fighting techniques.

element.name: Control Step
element.default: DX, Judo, Sumo Wrestling, Wrestling-2; cannot exceed default+2.
element.desc:
This technique uses the same location penalties as Control Torso (above). Both you and your opponent may substitute HP for ST in the Grappling Contest. With Control Step, you can move a standing opponent around, by forcing him to step and/or turn with you, or by changing his facing relative to you. Do both at the same time with -1. Changing his relative facing between front and rear or between opposite sides requires an additional -2.
Defensively, use Control Step to stop your opponent from stepping or turning. If your foe is crouching, take -2 to Control Step. Spinning your foe around is harder when he grapples you; see Taking the Back (Pyramid 3/34: Alternate GURPS, p. 14).
This technique is necessary to take a step while grappling, as you need to force your opponent to move. If you are only moving, without turning yourself or your opponent, you may ignore the number of hands/limbs you are grappling with and instead use a flat +1, by pushing or pulling with your full body.

element.name: Pin (Body Part)
element.default: DX+2, Judo, Sumo Wrestling, Wrestling+2; cannot exceed default.
element.desc:
A pin is a special case of control. If you are pressing your opponent against the ground, by being positioned on top, use Pin (Body Part) instead of Control (Body Part) to defensively stop that part from moving. If you are pressing him against a vertical immobile surface, like a wall, take -1 (which is still a net bonus over Control).
Pin (Body Part) uses the same penalties as Control (Body Part) for affecting adjacent body parts; thus, an attempt to Pin Torso would be at -2 if the closest body part you have grappled is the arm, whether you are directly pressing the torso or the arm. You may substitute HP for ST when pinning.

element.name: Takedown
element.default: DX-1, Judo-1, Sumo Wrestling-1, Wrestling-3; cannot exceed default.
element.desc:
Takedown uses the same location penalties as Control Torso or Control Leg (see Pyramid 3/34: Alternate GURPS, p. 14); gain +1 if you have both legs grappled or your foe is standing on one leg. Each extra free leg (past the default two) that you have not grappled gives -1.
Specify the direction in which your target will topple; he must land prone, face up, or on his side, with his lower body in his starting hex. If you elect to let go at the end of the technique, he chooses his final posture; otherwise, you decide.
You have three mutually exclusive options for “sacrificing’’ your own posture: • For +3, fall alongside him, dropping to your choice of prone, face-up, or on your side. You may not change your relative facing. You may substitute HP for ST. • For +2, pull him down with you, dropping to a kneeling or sitting posture. You may substitute HP for ST. • For +1, “reap’’ his leg using one of your own; he must have at least one free leg, and you must have at least two.
Immediately after the Takedown, whether you succeed or fail, make a DX roll to not fall over.

element.name: Judo Throw (Alternate)
element.default: DX-2, Judo-2, Sumo Wrestling-2, Wrestling-4; cannot exceed default.
element.desc:
This technique involves upending or lifting your opponent. It uses Control Torso’s location penalties (see Pyramid 3/34: Alternate GURPS, p. 14), and may be used with Takedown’s sacrificial options (above). You must be standing.
Choose which hexes your opponent lands in when you start to throw; they must overlap or be adjacent to his starting hex. Your foe takes damage as a fall from half of your height (see Falling, GURPS Basic Set, p. 431). You may “drive’’ him to the ground with -1, substituting your thrust damage (+1 for a hard ground surface).
How he lands, and where he takes damage, has five options: • Land him on his back, lying face-up. This is the default, and damage is to his torso. • Land him prone (face-down) with -1. Damage is to his torso. • Land him on his side with -1. Damage is to that side’s arm. • Land him on his head with -2, after which he falls face-up or on his side. Roll 1d: on a result of 1-3, damage is to his neck; 4-6 indicates skull damage. • Land him on his head with -3, after which he falls prone. Roll 1d: on a result of 1-3, damage is to his neck; 4-5 damages his skull; 6 damages his face.

element.name: Breakfall (Alternate)
element.prereq: Acrobatics, Judo, Sumo Wrestling, or Wrestling; cannot exceed prerequisite skill+4.
element.desc:
This technique lets you control a fall and reduce damage from being thrown. Roll against Breakfall to reduce the effective height of a fall – including from a Judo Throw – by five yards. If the thrower “drove’’ you to the ground for thrust-based damage, a successful Breakfall reduces damage by 1 plus your margin of success.
If you are landing on your head, Breakfall is at -1. You can change your final landing posture from side to face-up or prone, or vice versa, for -1. You can change it from face-up to prone, prone to face-up, or one side to the other for -2.
If your thrower chose to let go of you, you may roll to a crouch, in the farthest landing hex, for -3. Otherwise, you can flip over into a crouch, still grappled, for -5.

element.name: Wrench Arm (Alternate)
element.default: DX-3, Judo-3, Sumo Wrestling-5, Wrestling-3; cannot exceed default+3.
element.desc: Damage is to the arm; it requires an arm grapple, or takes -2 for a hand grapple.

element.name: Wrench Wrist/Finger (Alternate)
element.default: DX-4, Judo-4, Sumo Wrestling-6, Wrestling-4; cannot exceed default+4.
element.desc: Damage is to the hand. It requires a hand grapple.

element.name: Wrench Leg (Alternate)
element.default: DX-4, Judo-4, Sumo Wrestling-6, Wrestling-4; cannot exceed default+4.
element.desc: Damage is to the leg. It requires a leg grapple, or takes -2 for a foot grapple.

element.name: Wrench Ankle (Alternate)
element.default: DX-4, Judo-4, Sumo Wrestling-6, Wrestling-4; cannot exceed default+4.
element.desc: Damage is to the foot. It requires a foot grapple.

element.name: Wrench Neck (Alternate)
element.default: DX-3, Judo-3, Sumo Wrestling-5, Wrestling-3; cannot exceed default+3.
element.desc: Damage is to the neck. It requires a neck or head grapple.

element.name: Wrench Spine (Alternate)
element.default: DX-5, Judo-5, Sumo Wrestling-7, Wrestling-5; cannot exceed default+3.
element.desc: Damage is to the spine. It requires a torso grapple, done with at least two body parts.

element.name: Bear Hug
element.default: DX-4, Judo-4, Sumo Wrestling-6, Wrestling-4; cannot exceed default+1.
element.desc: Damage is to the torso; it requires a torso grapple. With -2, the victim instead takes fatigue damage as you squeeze out their breath.

element.name: Choke
element.default: DX-2, Judo-2, Sumo Wrestling-4, Wrestling-2; cannot exceed default+2.
element.desc: This requires a neck grapple and damages the neck. It can cut off air: if at least 1 point of damage gets past DR, the victim loses 1 fatigue and begins to suffocate. With -2, you may perform a carotid choke instead, which inflicts fatigue damage.

element.name: Head Crush
element.default: DX-4, Judo-4, Sumo Wrestling-6, Wrestling-4; cannot exceed default+1.
element.desc: Damage is to the skull, which still has DR 2; it requires a head grapple. With -1, you instead inflict pain as per the Wrench techniques (Pyramid 3/34: Alternate GURPS, p. 16).

element.name: Beheading Blow
element.prereq: Any Melee Weapon skill capable of swung cutting attacks; cannot exceed prerequisite skill-2.
element.desc: This technique lets slayers buy off the -5 to hit the neck when swinging an edged weapon. It’s valuable against vampires, liches, and other foes susceptible primarily (or only) to beheading.

element.name: Neck Bite
element.prereq: Sharp Teeth or Fangs and Brawling; cannot exceed Brawling-2.
element.desc: This is a common technique for vampires who find themselves in repeated combat or consider themselves to be great hunters. Werewolves use it just for fun (and some like to follow it up with Neck Snap, GURPS Basic Set, p. 232).

element.name: Stake to the Heart
element.prereq: Any Melee Weapon skill capable of thrusting impaling attacks; cannot exceed prerequisite skill-2.
element.desc: This technique is most often used with wooden stakes of varying lengths, including improvised stakes such as chair legs and pool cues. It lets slayers buy off the penalty to thrust for the heart with an impaling weapon. It defaults at -5, and not at -3 as for a shot to the vitals, because the target zone is smaller – hitting the lungs, kidneys, etc., has no effect on the undead!

element.name: Strangle Hold
element.prereq: Judo, Sumo Wrestling, or Wrestling; cannot exceed prerequisite skill.
element.desc: Mummies, disembodied hands (spectral and corporeal), and even a few rippers enjoy this technique. It lets would-be throttlers buy off the penalty to grapple the neck in order to set up a strangle (GURPS Basic Set, p. 370).

element.name: True Tarot
element.prereq: Precognition and Fortune-Telling (Tarot); cannot exceed Fortune-Telling (Tarot).
element.desc:
Many precogs subconsciously rely on fortune-telling impedimenta (e.g., crystal balls, yarrow sticks, or tarot cards) or methods (such as palm-reading or augury) to focus their gift. By dint of long training and psychic tuning to such “crutches,” the diviner can increase his odds with deliberate attempts to use Precognition (GURPS Basic Set, p. 77).
Other Fortune-Telling specialties have their own versions of this technique: True Augury, True I Ching, True Scrying, etc.

element.name: Blood Vessel Pressure
element.prereq: First Aid; cannot exceed First Aid skill.
element.desc:
This technique is a substitute for using a tourniquet (GURPS Low-Tech, p. 145). It can stop bleeding from the scalp, ear, or other location that can’t be tourniqueted but that has accessible blood vessels. The patient must be cooperative or restrained. The caregiver presses against an artery, reducing blood flow and slowing bleeding as for a successful First Aid roll. He may opt to make a ST-based (rather than IQ-based) roll. He must maintain the hold for a full minute, at the cost of 1 FP.
If using Bleeding (GURPS Basic Set, p. 420) and the initial Blood Vessel Pressure roll fails, the medic can maintain the hold at a cost of 1 FP per additional minute. Each minute allows another Blood Vessel Pressure roll, as well as the patient’s HT roll. If either succeeds, the wound doesn’t bleed in that minute.
At the GM’s discretion, this technique can also be based on Pressure Points skill. The prerequisite becomes Pressure Points; the default, Pressure Points-2; and the maximum level, Pressure Points+2.

element.name: Distillation
element.prereq: Alchemy or Chemistry; cannot exceed prerequisite skill+6.
element.desc:
Distillation is one of the basic methods for purifying chemical substances. It appears at late TL2, when Roman and Chinese experimenters begin to develop alchemy and chemistry (the two aren’t clearly distinguished until TL5). It’s used to produce alcohol (GURPS Low-Tech, p. 25), among other things.
Roll against Chemistry skill for distillation. The proper temperature is vital and must be judged by observation; a distiller can improve his judgment up to Chemistry+6 using this technique. In a TL5+ lab or distillery, with accurate thermometers, getting the right temperature is easy and the full +6 is automatic. Early thermometers, before Fahrenheit’s (see Temperature and Pressure, GURPS Low-Tech, p. 45), are less accurate, giving only +4. Thermometer bonuses replace technique bonuses; the two never add.
Success doubles the concentration of the desired substance; critical success means the yield is nearly pure. Failure doesn’t change the concentration. Critical failure produces the wrong substance, or (at the GM’s discretion) causes a lab accident such as a burst vessel or a fire.

element.name: Hands-Free Driving
element.prereq: Teamster (Equines); cannot exceed Teamster (Equines)-1.
element.desc: Chariot warriors don’t normally drive their own chariots – their hands are occupied with weapons. They leave the task to a charioteer. If the driver is disabled or unavailable, though, a warrior may loop the reins about his waist or fasten them to his belt, steering by leaning against them. This is never as good as having the reins in hand, and it’s risky; if the chariot is disabled, he’ll be dragged over the ground! He also can’t dodge without losing control of the horses; treat this as a control roll failed by SR or less (see Control Rolls, GURPS Basic Set, p. 466).

element.name: Mounted Reload
element.prereq: Guns and Riding; cannot exceed lower prerequisite skill.
element.desc:
Mounted Reload lets you load a muzzleloader while mounted; see Loading (GURPS Low-Tech, p. 94-95). You must specialize by Guns specialty and Riding specialty. Failure means starting over; critical failure means a dropped weapon, spilled powder or shot, or an extinguished match (matchlock or cannonlock only).
This feat is two-handed. Use Hands-Free Riding (above) for riding more complex than straight-line travel. Any failure means you must start over, in addition to its other bad effects.

element.name: Quick Mount
element.prereq: Acrobatics, Jumping, or Riding; cannot exceed prerequisite skill.
element.desc: For riders before the invention of the stirrup, getting onto a horse was a challenge. It required either stepping onto a mounting block or vaulting onto the horse’s back using this technique. See Mounting Up (GURPS Basic Set, p. 396).
